qas.question: Who thought Burke should have written in a more moderate tone?
Who said he 'perfectly differed from Mr. Fox'?
What was Francis Basset's political party?
How did Burke think the Whigs secretly felt?
Who thought Burke and Fox shouldn't have made their argument public?
Who did Burke want to use more moderate language?
What type of Whig was Fitzwilliam?
Who claimed to be similar to Mr. Fox?
Who did Basset send a copy of his letter to?
Who wanted the argument to go public?

context: Although Whig grandees such as <a0_0><b5_0>Portland and Fitzwilliam<b5_0/><a0_0/> privately agreed with Burke's Appeal, they wished he had used more moderate language. Fitzwilliam saw the Appeal as containing "the doctrines I have sworn by, long and long since". <a1_0><b7_0>Francis Basset<b7_0/><a1_0/>, <b6_0>a backbench <a2_0>Whig<a2_0/> MP,<b6_0/> wrote to Burke: "...though for reasons which I will not now detail I did not then deliver my sentiments, I most perfectly differ from Mr. Fox & from the great Body of opposition on the French Revolution". Burke sent a copy of the Appeal to <b8_0>the king<b8_0/> and the king requested a friend to communicate to Burke that he had read it "with great Satisfaction". Burke wrote of its reception: "Not one word from one of our party. They are secretly <a3_0>galled<a3_0/>. They agree with me to a title; but they dare not speak out for fear of hurting Fox. ... They leave me to myself; they see that I can do myself justice". <a4_0><b9_0>Charles Burney<b9_0/><a4_0/> viewed it as "a most admirable book—the best & most useful on political subjects that I have ever seen" but believed the differences in the Whig Party between Burke and Fox should not be aired publicly.
